conversation.message: Simplify 4(x - 1) - 3x.

First, distribute 4 across (x - 1): 4(x) = 4x and 4(-1) = -4. Substitute this into the expression: 4x - 4 - 3x. Now, combine the x-terms: 4x - 3x = x. The simplified expression is x - 4. Do you understand this step?

Why do we distribute 4 to both x and -1?

Good question! The distributive property tells us to multiply 4 by every term inside the parentheses. This ensures the expression remains equivalent. So, 4(x - 1) becomes 4x - 4. Does that make sense?
